comment: Really love the idea and can admire Lacerda's design chops but like many of his games, I found everything too opaque, taking actions and hoping for the best only to learn three-turns-later that I should done X-action instead of Y-action and I could've had a super monster ultra-chain-reaction turn this round. I suppose you start to see those possibilities develop the more you play the game and become familiar with its intricacies, but the problem is that for me to want to devote that much time to exploring a game's nooks and crannies, the game must first be \superficially\ enjoyable, and this often felt more like studious work than fun. Very fiddly, long setup and teardown time, long play time, and yet again loaded with a lot of random endgame scoring tiles that reward players for doing things they would otherwise be doing anyway.

Who cares that the box weighs 2lbs more than the last game he released? Is this the new Lacerda metric of game evolution? Some idiot actually showed pictures of this in the forum, comparing "large boxes, large tiles" to normal boxes, like it was a good reason to pay $130 more. Is this the new measure of game quality? These are detriments to me. I don't need boxes that are twice the size of a normal box, that don't fit on the shelf. I read his next kickstarter game, 'The kitchenist', includes a 1.5 inch thick game board made out of alderwood and maple that can also be used for chopping brocolli. Only $250 if you pledge now.

The fact that Lacerda is okay with this price gouging is disturbing. Is the game three times as good as Trajan, Keyflower, Vinhos, which cost $50? If so, sign me up, because it's the second coming of Christ. Hallelujah! All hail the new God.

What is even more sad is that the game might be good, but Lacerda is going to not only lose many potential NEW customers because of the pricing, he's going to lose old customers, who already know his games, but are sick of the price gouging. This company makes Splotter look bargain bin. Hey, EGG, whatever rocks your boat. If you want to pimp out games to the top 0.01% of the population who are happy to pay this amount of money, and find solace in your elitist prestige of "limited run of 500" to justify this cost, fine. Maybe put a big sticker on the box: "Your $180 helps Vital design games full-time." With this company, and with this pricing, it appears Vital no longer cares about his games getting into as many hands as possible. Strange modus operandi from a game designer. Sure, I'll kickstart this...with my foot right up EGG's ass.

Explanation of the rules takes around 60 minutes and is stuffed with plenty of tiny, abstract and counterintuitive rules hard to remember. This is what I call “not elegant game”. The recipe for such a game is always the same. Invent as much as possible bizarre elements (e.g. clockwise walking bishop collecting modifiers to the rules), intertwine them artificially with each other to create a maze of interdependent abstract factors and variables, lastly let count the victory points on almost everything and don’t bother with the length of the rulebook. Geeks will swallow any. The player aid is the 8 pages tiny printed booklet full of icons. Don’t even try to play the game without it.

The only elegant element here is the idea of de-rubbling the damaged city. In the beginning it’s very expensive as there’s plenty of rubble to remove. But gradually as the rubble is being removed by the players it gets easier and cheaper. Cool.

Refer to “Troyes” to see how abstract, heavy, equally challenging, time-reasonable and elegant euro game of similar vibe and theme can look like.

What a disappointment this was for us. I don't understand the weight rating, it was easy to learn. I triple checked we weren't missing any rules, but this game wasn't deep enough.

The theme was awesome the first game, my wife and I both loved the history, and the theme really comes across.

But I think even despite having variable setup, this game just felt too stale. It was not fun. Both times at the end, my wife (who even won both games) was like "wow, that's it?" Despite playing for 2 hours, it feels like weren't that many turns, and it just feels like you didn't do enough in the game, even when doing all kinds of neat combos.

I think our biggest problem came in that the actions were very simple. You have only 4 to choose from, and some of those let you choose another 6 possible actions. It's not very deep, all actions are extremely simple and straightforward, it is not a brain burner. It's very easy to plan ahead in this game, the setup is variable, but being able to draw from four individual decks, and having 5 cards, well, it's a lot different than say Brass where you draw from a common deck. Most games that we like, we master easy enough, so it's wonderful to have some mechanic that adds a little bit of randomness you have to adjust to as an added challenge. This game doesn't have that mechanic, or enough of it, so in a 2 player game at least, it feels like you can pretty much accomplish everything, planning far enough ahead and not have to sweat much. The only exception is when other person takes public architect plan you wanted, but you can have several contingencies built in because 3 other are visible.

Overall, it results in a boring game for my wife and I. I don't mind games with less random in them if they are deeper and make us think harder, but this one felt way too easy. It's not junk, and I'd play it rather than play nothing at all, but there are so many other games both my wife and myself would rather play.

It is becoming so relaxing and comfortable to play the beginning of a Lacerda game, knowing that as intertwined as everything is and as scarce as some resources are, I won't shoot myself in the foot as much as I fear if I just kinda do some stuff and see where it goes.

But the endgame that comes with those dynamics is less charming for me. There's somehow a few less plot twists than I want, or something. Even though there can be very dramatic late-game swings from specific moves (in this case, I got 15 points from a single building-- the maximum possible, I think).

• In Lisboa you are navigating an extensive array of intricate, interrelated mechanisms with the goal of accumulating points in the most efficient way.
• If you find complexity engaging, you’ll like Lisboa for this aspect.
• The game’s mechanisms support the historical theme quite well.
• The rulebook does not give a sense for how to approach play. There are interrelationships between several of the procedural subroutines that are not initially apparent, and these connections aren’t highlighted by the organization of the rules. This is all to say there’s a steep learning curve. Fortunately, there are third party references available here in the BGG files section that do a better job of conveying these procedural dependencies.
• Is Lisboa fun? The answer is very subjective.

Lisboa offers a more interesting and impressive design than delivering on fun factor. The complexity of the ruleset leads to turns that feel a little overly procedural and convoluted. There are a couple elements, like shipping, which feel like they're less well integrated with the rest of the game. While the puzzle is crunchy, Lisboa doesn't stand out in terms of what emotions it can evoke and any unique feelings this game can offer in comparison to everything else.

Clergy: conceptually wonderful, but I feel that this mechanism is awkward at best, adding what I consider too high a complexity/crunch ratio. Its tiles are small - Reference numbers on tiles are near impossible to read without aid if you use even the mildest of prescription glasses/readers, and keeping track of (remembering) the bonuses associated with them (along with others) during the course of play can be annoying. They just slow gameplay down quite a bit.

In 1755, the city of Lisbon, Portugal (called Lisboa by its residents) suffered a devastating earthquake, which created a devastating tsunami, and then devastating fires which burned for days. It's time to rebuild, and you're in charge. You'll need to clear the rubble, fires, and floodwaters in order to build new shops and public buildings. You'll also want to restart the economy by producing goods, building trade ships and shipping goods, and, most importantly, collecting wigs. What? That's right. Apparently wigs were a real sign of wealth in this time and place and so that is how the victory points are represented.

In a sense, the turn structure is quite simple: you play a card from your hand of five, do what it says, then draw a replacement card. But describing the game this way is almost comically reductionist. Each card has two different ways it can be played in two different locations, for a total of four possibilities. A card played to the first location will grant you the bonus of the card, then allow you to take up to two of seven possible actions, each requiring resource payments of various kinds. A card played to the second location requires a totally different payment type and then will grant one of four completely different actions than the aforementioned seven or else perform yet another action as dictated by the card itself. And each individual action can require carrying out as many as seven sequential steps. Oh, and in some cases, other players can also piggyback onto the action you've chosen.

Fortunately, the player aids are extremely helpful in this regard. Each player receives their own, fully eight-pages, color-printed and stapled into a booklet. They even include a section that is a real boon to new players, including answers to questions like "How can I get more money?" and "When do I have to spend influence?" So many games of this type have clearly defined goals, but leave players baffled on how to accomplish them. That's not the case here, to its credit. But let's be clear, as useful and necessary as these player aids are, they exceed the length of the complete rules for many other board games.

Games like Lisboa should probably come with a warning label. This is a triple-black-diamond in terms of rules complexity, mandating at least an hour of teaching. If you dropped your jaw or burst out in incredulous laughter at that statement, you'll get no judgment from me; this game is clearly not for everyone. And yet, the various sections of the game are so seamlessly-integrated and elegantly-designed that there is no way to remove even a small portion without lessening the experience. This integration is also what makes the teaching process so challenging: every mechanic is so interconnected that there is no good place to start. Lisboa is a game that you should play regularly, or not at all. With the time invested into learning it, it's quite rewarding with lots of paths to explore and a ton of strategic depth. But your gaming life won't be any less rich if you decide to skip this one.

The premise of Lisboa is intriguing: players make their mark after the 1755 earthquake that nearly destroyed present-day Lisbon. Help rebuild the city by working with key cultural figures to clear rubble, establish manufacturers, and develop commerce. This is done by choosing a card to either improve one’s portfolio (which provides some passive benefit) or interact with the influential powers (to take one of the game’s primary actions). The mechanics intersect well, with each played card sending a ripple effect on the game state. Building a ship improves the the city’s wealth and opens up the opportunity for any player to make fast money. Erecting a public building opens up a victory point condition at the cost of committing one’s political sway.

The multi-step actions (and iconography) do increase the game’s inherent complexity, so expect a front-loaded learning curve. Expectations are important to manage for any heavy Euro and Lisboa is no different. Within its inviting azulejo blue-and-white color palette lies an efficiency puzzle with incidental interactions from other players. Such a premise might cause a general feeling of ambivalence for me, but I was drawn in. As is the ilk with Lacerda’s stronger offerings, Lisboa’s thematic appeal helps translate its Euro abstractions. An initial impression of a point generation sandbox evolved into something more intricate and interesting with continued plays. This was a passion project and it shows.

This took me forever to click and internalize, mostly because the game is most definitely not as clean or as elegant of a design as Lacerda fans would have you believe. I know the whole “play a card, draw a card” -explanation is kind of a meme to begin with, but that whole multi-use card thing with playing into different areas and those decisions branching into multiple different actions themselves is actually really unintuitive, unthematic, and confusing. Especially when each action comes with a lot of fiddly minutiae and easily forgettable procedural steps.

Also I really don’t like the follow-mechanism. Yes, it makes you more efficient and yes, figuring out how to leech off extra actions from other players makes the game extra crunchy. However ultimately it’s equally as intrusive as with The Gallerist - the game flow becomes clunky and awkward when people keep taking full actions out of turn order, and the downtime can also get pretty bonkers. Finally the end-game decree card rush feels kind of wonky and weird, makes sense that this was since “patched” with the Queen variant.

Excuse the ranting as I’m kind of tired of overly complex euro games of this ilk, but even still once you get past the initial unintuitiveness and learn to accept the unavoidable amount of fiddle that comes with a Lacerda game, the game becomes really enjoyable. The interconnectivity of the different actions and areas of the game makes the action sequencing puzzle fascinating. The central area with re-building the city is also more interactive than initially seems, good opportunities of making use of other people’s work and there’s even an interesting minor element of shared incentives there. I would potentially even rate this higher if played with a lower player count as you’d have more actions and less downtime, but for now a cautious eight feels about right.

Flawless game. This is the ideal state of interwoven mechanics all synergizing with each other while also being supported by the theme. The action mechanism is clever and fresh. On most turns, you’ll agonize over your past choices and limited resources. However, some turns are simply amazing, when your planning pays off.

The game flowing almost as fast in 4 players as it does in 2 is a pleasant surprise and a proof of the designer’s skill. The game also offers multiple points of interaction. After all, you're rebuilding the same city and visiting the same nobility. You really care and are influenced by the actions of people around the table.

Although mechanics are prioritized to theme, the theme is greatly utilized. From the different colored cubes to the flow of the game represented by passing years, everything reinforces the sense of rebuilding after a great catastrophe.

For me, Lisboa has three primary strengths: (1) it's gratifyingly juicy and thinky (with lots of options to consider and plan for), (2) the city-building theme is cohesively integrated and interesting (though slightly dry), and (3) there is strong replayability due to the randomization of the various setup elements and the different paths you can take in the game. So it gets a solid score from me, based on 4P. Yes, there is a big learning curve and a huge number of symbols to absorb, but I see this being merely a temporary hump. Total play time is reasonable.

With 4P, it's a bit chaotic, with a constant changing board state, and as a result player interaction is not as relevant as I would like. I can see player interaction becoming much more meaningful at 2P. 3P may very well be sweet spot and the best overall player count. Will update my rating (likely higher) once I have played 2P and 3P.

Lisboa casts you into the heart of a city rising from ashes. After the devastating earthquake of 1755, you take on the role of a noble, shaping streets, erecting buildings, and guiding the city toward a new future.

The game flows along a winding path of card draws and plays, each choice opening doors to negotiate with the king, marshal resources, or expand your influence. Every decision feels consequential, every move a step in the intricate dance of rebuilding.

Amid the shadow of tragedy, the game sparkles with strategy: a competitive race for the most coveted plots, clever placement of shops, and meticulous resource management. The city grows under your hand, a living puzzle of streets, squares, and ambition.

With each play, the mechanisms reveal their depth: careful planning, subtle interaction, and the constant tension of opportunity versus risk. Lisboa is both a simulation of reconstruction and a poetic journey through history, where time slips away as the city takes shape under your guidance.
